loans.name: Yambo

texts.en: Yambo M. is a widow and a mother of four children.  Her husband died twenty-three years ago leaving her full responsibility of his children. She  engages in the buying and selling of agriculture produce.  Yambo buys the products from farmers in wholesale and sells them to her customers on retail.  Through her business, she is able to educate her children.  One of her children has joined the college and Yambo hopes to see him through.  She is therefore requesting a loan to expand her business and to renovate their family home.  Her future plan is to develop a oil palm plantation for her children.   Yambo is forty-five years old.

loans.use: Expansion of agricultural produce business.

loans.name: Alfiya

texts.ru:
Alfiya, 43, is married and has a son and a daughter. Her husband earns enough to provide for the family, but Alfiya does not want to sit home, so she sells women’s clothing and underwear on the market. In 2003, she received her first MicroInvest loan. The money helped Alfiya expand and develop her business. Recently, she occupied a small store. Alfiya plans to use this loan to purchase warm dressing gowns.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Альфие 43 года, она замужем, у нее дочь и сын. Ее муж зарабатывает достаточно для проживания семьи, но Альфия не хочет сидеть дома без дела и поэтому выходит на базар торговать. В ассортименте ее товаров женские халаты и нижнее белье. В Микроинвест первый займ получила в 2003 году. Займы помогли ей расшириться и внесли изменения в ее бизнес. Недавно она совместно с администрацией базара оборудовала маленький магазинчик. С новым займ она собирается обновить ассортимент теплых халатов.

loans.use: To purchase warm dressing gowns

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth E. is a very active and enterprising woman. She is married and has 3 children; she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old. She sells drinks and has been in this business since 1994.  Ruth is requesting  a loan of US$ 400 to enable her buy more drinks for sale, which she plans to repay within eight months.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale

loans.name: Margaret's Group

texts.en:
Margaret M. sells clothing and charcoal. She sells her charcoal and clothing outside and, when it rains, her stock is damaged. With a loan, Margaret wants to build her own store. With her profits she will pay her children’s school fees and build her own home (rather than renting it as she does now).

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Phun

texts.en: Mrs. Phun I., 34, is a widow and lives with her two sisters and two brothers in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. To help with her family’s expenses, Mrs. Phun I. works raising pigs and reselling them for a profit. After finding out about CREDIT MFI from her neighbor, she decided to ask for a loan to expand her livestock by adding more pigs for breeding. She believes her income will steadily increase about six to seven months after the purchase.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs.

loans.name: Karina

texts.es:
Mrs. Karina belongs to The Pearls of Pucallpa Communal Bank, located at 206 Jr. Libertad St., in the district of Calleria, the state of Ucayali. Karina is 23 years old, she is the mother of 1 son and her husband is a professional. With the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles she decided to invest in a beauty salon. Nowadays she has a beauty salon where in an organized manner she tends to it and also her domestic chores. With the loan of 1800 soles, which she will pay in 5 months, she will invest in the purchase of liquids, dyes, nail polishes, shampoo, creams, etc. Karina is a young mother, and because of her desire to contribute to the economic expenses of her family she decided to start a business. Now she feels more peaceful because in the future she will be able to give her child a better life.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

.La señora Karina pertenece al banco comunal Las Perlas de Pucallpa, ubicado en el Jr. Libertad N° 206, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Karina tiene 23 años, es madre de 1 hijo y su esposo es profesional. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300 decidió invertir en un salón de belleza. En la actualidad tiene un salón de estética y de belleza donde de manera muy organizada lo atiende y no descuida las labores domésticas. Con el préstamo de S/ 1,800 soles, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en comprar líquido ondulante, tintes, esmaltes, shampoo, cremas, etc. Karina es una madre muy joven, y por el deseo de contribuir a los ingresos económicos de su familia decidió poner un negocio. Ahora se siente mas tranquila porque en el futuro podrá darle lo mejor a su pequeño hijo.

loans.use: To purchase liquids, dyes, nail polishes, shampoo, etc.

loans.name: Hugo

texts.es:
Hugo owns amplifying and stereo equipment which he provides to parties, birthdays, and other social events. Hugo lives in Bajo Pampahasi on the eastern side of La Paz. This is the third time that Hugo has requested a loan from IMPRO.

Hugo’s loan history earns him a “1” rating, which signifies that he has completely repaid his prior loans in good order.

This loan will be used to purchase a complete set of equipment for integrating music (power supply, mixer, deck, CD player, and a set of lights). Hugo wishes to offer a better service to his clients. Hugo’s work and experience in the industry leads to the approval of this loan. He received his first loan from us in 2004.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Hugo tiene un equipo de amplificación para la animación de fiestas, cumpleaños y todo acontecimiento social. Su domicilio se encuentra ubicado en la zona de Bajo Pampahasi ladera este de la ciudad de La Paz, Es la tercera vez que solicita un crédito en Impro, su historial lo califica como cliente 1 es decir con cumplimiento bueno en el pago de su obligación; el crédito será destinado la compra de equipo completo de música integrado (Poder, mezcladora, deck, compactera y juego de luces), pues es su deseo poder ofrecer una mejor calidad a sus clientes. Su trabajo le permite acceder a este crédito ya que tiene experiencia en el rubro. Su primer crédito con nosotros data del año 2004.

loans.use: Purchase of a full set of equipment for his DJ business.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is a 72-year-old widow with six children and twenty grandchildren. She has been selling onions, salt, and garden eggs for the past twenty years. Due to her age, she has to rely on other traders to buy and sell her products in bulk to customers; even so, she still sells some of her products on her own on a table-top in the local market to maintain her physical strength.

Augustina is seeking a loan to buy more bags of onions, sacks of salt, and garden eggs.

She is a member of the group called “Sunkwa” (meaning, "think of Life"). Group members agree in principle to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional food products (e.g., onions, salt, and garden eggs).

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida (her husband is pictured) is a 41-year-old woman and the mother of 3 children. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan and has settled in the Fuzuli region in Kurdmahmudlu village. She works very hard with her husband for the success of their children.

They have run their dairy business for 10 years. By improving their business, they will be able to provide their family with better living conditions. Now they need a loan of $975 to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Zahia

texts.en: Zahia is 37 years old. She lives in a small village close to Nabatieh, in Southern Lebanon. Zahia arranges flowers for special events. Zahia would like a loan of $300 to purchase raw materials and artificial flowers to prepare floral arrangements. The wedding season is a very busy time of year for her, and she would like to use this opportunity to expand her business and clientele.

loans.use: To purchase flowers for floral arrangements

loans.name: Juzdy Nelly

texts.es:
Juzdy is married. Her husband works as a carpenter. She has a one year old child whose name is Francisco. She started the business because she is very active and wants to help her husband with household costs and giving a better quality of life to their child. She started selling clothes to her relatives three years go and now sells clothing and shoes to the public.

She needs a loan of $500, which she will pay in 6 months, in order to restock her merchandise. With your help, she will succeed.

Translated from the Spanish by Susanna Heinz, Kiva Volunteer.

Juzdy esta casada, su esposo trabaja como carpintero y tiene un hijo de un año, se llama Francisco. Inició el negocio por que es muy activa y aparte ayuda con los gastos de la csa a su esposo para tener un mayor ingreso para su familia y ofrecerle mejor calidad de vida a su hijo, comenzó hace tres años vendiendo a sus familiares ropa posteriomente empezó a vender ropa y zapatos al publico en general.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para poder surtir mercancia. Con tu ayuda ella saldra adelante.

loans.use: Purchasing merchandise

loans.name: Khit

texts.en:
Mrs. Khit C. lives in Takol Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She sells a kind of Khmer cake (kanlan), which she makes from sticky rice and beans. Mrs. C.'s customers find her cakes very delicious.

Her husband, Mr. Penh Pin, is a construction worker who builds houses, and is also a farmer. They have four children, two of whom are attending school, and two are too young to work or study.

Mrs. Khit C.'s family lives in an old house in poor conditions. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. C. is requesting a loan to add to her savings so they can build a new house for thier family.

loans.use: Add to savings to purchase materials to build a new house for the family

loans.name: Thị Lượng Chu Group

texts.vi:
Chị C. Thị Lượng 26 tuổi mã số 09050069 chị đi làm thuê òn chồng buôn bán hàng hóa. Chị cùng cả nhóm đã hoàn trả hết C. kỳ 1 và tiếp tục vay 3.808.000đ thời hạn 12 tháng để thêm vốn cho chồng đi chợ. thu nhập gia đình chị mỗi ngày từ 100.000 _120.000đ, với số tiền đó chị có thể chi tiêu cho gia đình và trả góp hàng tuần.Trong nhóm chị còn có 5 thành viên khác.

  • Ngô thị Nguyên mã số 09050070 vay 3808.000đ thời gian 12 tháng đê mua lợn giống và cám lợn.
  • Ngô thị Hà mã số 09050072 vay 3.808.000đ để mua cám.
  • Ngô Thị Thảo mã số 09050068 vay 3.808.000đ để mua lợn giống.
  • Ngô thị Ninh mã số 09050044 vay 3.660.000 để mua cám nuôi vịt đẻ trứng
  • T. Thị Lan mã số 09050115 vay vốn để đi chợ buôn bán hang tạp hóa như mỳ chính, kẹo bánh...
texts.en:
Mrs C. Thị Lượng is 26 years old. She works on contract. Her husband sells basic goods. Her group has already paid back their first loan. She is requesting a loan of 3.808.000 VND for her husband to invest in his business. Her family income is 100.000 - 120.000 VND a day. This is used to pay for daily expenses and the weekly payment. Her group has 5 other members:
  • Ngô thị Nguyên, seeking 3808.000 VND to buy breeding pigs and feed.
  • Ngô thị Ha, seeking 3.808.000đ VND to buy feed
  • Ngô Thị Thảo, seeking 3.808.000 VND to buy brreding pigs
  • Ngô thị Ninh, seeking 3.660.000 VND to buy feed for her ducks
  • T. Thị Lan , she sells basic goods

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy basic goods to resell

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
La señora Maria, socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen del Rosario”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia y distrito de Bellavista y caserío de La Libertad. Se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y comida y su negocio está ubicado en su casa en el Jr. Porvenir Mz. C Lt. 7.  Se inicia en el negocio porque tenía la necesidad de generar sus ingresos para solventar los gastos de sus hijos, sobre todo los gastos escolares.  

Con este préstamo de S/.1,100., el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará agua mineral, gaseosas de diferentes marcas y de tamaño personal, mediano y familiar, así como los productos para la preparación de sus platos a ofertar a sus clientes. 

Maria tiene 41 años de edad, vive con su esposo y con uno de sus 02 hijos. Es una mujer muy perseverante y responsable, con ganas de sacar adelante a su negocio y a sus hijos. Más adelante desea arreglar e implementar su local para darle una buena imagen y prestigio en la localidad.
texts.en:
María, a member of the Virgen del Rosario community bank, lives in the village of La Libertad, in the province and district of Bellavista, in San Martín region. She deals in soft drinks and food, and her business is located in her home in Porvenir, on lot 7, block C. María began her business because she needed to generate income in order to cover her children’s expenses, especially all the school expenses. With this six-month $375 loan (1,100 nuevos soles), she will buy bottled water, various brands of soft drinks in individual, medium and family sizes, as well as ingredients for preparing the dishes she serves to her customers. María is 41 years old, and lives with her husband and one of their two children. She is a very diligent and responsible woman, who wants both her children and her business to prosper. In the future, she would like to refurbish her eatery to make a good impression and raise its prestige in the community.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bottled water and soft drinks, as well as other products

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: La señora Rosa, cliente de Emprender desde hace varios añosa, se dedica a la venta de ropa y accesorios, desarrolla su actividad de forma ambulante, ya tiene su clientela asegurada y son personas con quienes trabaja hace bastante tiempo, vende productos a crédito con cierta facilidad de pago en cuotas ya sean estas diarias o semanales, con las ganancias ella llega a cubrir los gastos familiares, hace estudiar a su hija, quien aun esta a su cargo. Vive en una zona alejada de la ciudad de La Paz y es muy sacrificada en su trabajo. Actualmente solicita el sexto credito teniendo un historial de credito impecable.
texts.en:
Mrs Rosa, who has been receiving loans from Emprender for various years now, is a peddler selling clothes and accessories for a living. She now has regular customers with whom she has been working for quite a while. She sells her products in credit with certain easy payment terms, which are in either daily or weekly instalments. With her earnings she is able to cover the family’s expenses and pay for her daughter's education, who is also her responsibility. She lives in a remote part of the city of La Paz and she is extremely selfless when it comes to her job. She now requests her sixth loan with a history of always repaying them on time.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Roden-Scott, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase capital

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
Immaculate is married to Nkain Cletus, and they are blessed with six children, two of which are below 15 years of age. They live in a three-room house in Nanga-Street, a quarter in Bamenda-NW regions in Cameroon. Immaculate has decided to work extra hard to assist her husband to address the needs of such a big family. She has faced so many challenges in life such as inadequate funds to sustain her business project and ill health. These challenges made life uncomfortable for her, until 18th September 2007 when she discovered GHAPE and became a member. In that same year, Immaculate received her first loan of 40,000FRS and her repayment was successful. The profit she made was plowed back into her business capital of buying and selling. 

Given a loan, she plans to buy firewood for 50,000FRS, dry corn and groundnuts for 46,500FRS, two buckets of groundnuts for 16,0000FRS, koki beans for 21,000FRS, two bags of salt, and magi for 27,500FRS and transportation for 29,000FRS.  She plans to contribute 90,000FRS ($180 USD) of her own personal savings in order to carry out this business plan.  

Immaculate will start repayments from the day the loan is disbursed.  She is quite convinced the business will succeed because of her manner of approach to her customers, the way she usually displays her goods and the experience she is already having in the business. Her business will help her community through the taxes she will be paying will help to foster the economic growth in the area. With the profit from the business, she plans to pay her children school fees, and uses part to expand on her business. She prefer to receive loans from GHAPE because of the social education GHAPE due offers, and the method of repayment is convenient.

loans.use: Buying and selling of corn, Beans, and Groundnut.

loans.name: Rosas

texts.es:
Rosas es socia del Banco Comunal Inti que quiere decir Sol en quechua.
Rosas es conviviente, tiene 25 años y 1 hijo, Rosas vende ropa a pedidos, sus productos los ofrece a amigos, familiares, conocidos, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima a donde viaja semanalmente. 
Rosas necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa variada.
Los sueños de Rosas son salir adelante, incrementar su capital y que su hijo sea profesional.
texts.en:
Rosas is a member of the Inti community bank, a name that comes from the Quechuan word for "sun". Rosas, 25, is partnered and has 1 son. She operates a clothing business, selling her products to friends, family, and acquaintances. She goes to Lima weekly to buy merchandise. Rosas needs a 1200-soles loan, money that she will invest in buying inventory. Rosas hopes to get ahead, grow her capital and see her son take up a professional career.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Alison

texts.es:
La señorita Alison vive en casa de sus padres en la Av. Buenos Aires de la zona de San Martín de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja en una tienda vendiendo joyas de plata.
El crédito que solicita es para comprar billetes de alasita y armar canastitas para vender en la feria de esta manera mejorar sus ingresos. “Alasita” es una feria anual que comienza el 24 de Enero y termina tres semanas después, donde todos los productos artesanales que se venden son miniaturas, desde billetes hasta casas.

No es cliente de Impro pero por la actividad y el carácter social califica para obtener un crédito.
texts.en:
Alison lives with her parents in the neighbourhood of San Martín in La Paz; she works in a store selling silver jewelry. She is asking for a loan to buy miniature money for the festival of Alasita and prepare small baskets to sell at the festival so that she can earn more money. The festival of Alastita is an annual celebration which starts on January 24 and lasts three weeks and where all sorts of products are made in miniature and sold, everything from money to houses. She is not a client of Impro but the nature of this activity and her reputation qualify her for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy miniatures to sell during the festival of Alasita.

loans.name: Ma.shellane

texts.en:
Ma.Shellane P. raises pigs in her backyard. She is 39 years old and has 2 children. Her husband Elmer P. helps her to raise the pigs. This augments their limited income.

Previously, Ma.Shellane worked as a food vendor, where she sold a variety of snack items like peanuts, cassava rolls and other street foods. Now, she raises hogs because she loves the work. She is also convinced that she will earn a bigger profit from raising hogs.

Ma.Shellane is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 4 piglets, pre-starter feeds, vaccines and anti-bacterial medicine. She believes that she will earn a bigger profit if she takes good care of the pigs; she will be able to sell them for more money. She hopes that with the money she earns, she will be able to send her children to college.

CEVI is helping Ma.Shellane grow her hog business. She has access to credit assistance, training and insurance coverage. CEVI helps all of its clients in these ways.

loans.use: To buy 4 piglets and feed

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. Ny P. lives in Chhoer Teal village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate vegetables to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Yin Yun, is a fisherman. Although they try to work hard, they still earn little income to support their family. Mrs. Ny P. decided to ask for a loan to add her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family.

She is a 50-year-old mother of seven children, two of whom are fishermen while others are farmers. Two of the children are enrolled in the local school and the remaining is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To add to her savings to buy timbers to build a house for her family.

loans.name: Tolib

texts.ru: Толиб клиент в Микроинвест с 2007 года.Его бизнес, продажа продуктов питания и кулинарных изделий, тортов , пирожный.Поставляют ему поставщики с кондитерских цехов.Его магазин расположен в центре рынка города Костакоз.У него постоянно торговля кипит.Следующий займ он хочет потратить на закуп напитков, соков.Он благодарен всем инвесторам за финансирование и давшую ему возможность расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Tolib has been a client of MicroInvest since 2007. His business is selling food and bakery products, such as cakes and pastries. His suppliers are large bakeries. Tolib’s store is located in the center of the market in Kostakoz. His business is consistently booming. He wants to use this loan to purchase beverages and juice. He is grateful to all investors for the financing that enabled Tolib to grow his business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Food products

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en:
Semeni has been a clothes seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for two years. She belongs to R'haigawanywi group loan (Group code 2080). She currently earns an average monthly profit of $70. Every day she works at her business for eight hours.

Semeni is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes to sell so as to expand her business. She is hoping that, through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, improve her home and pay school fees for her children.

Semeni is 33 years old, married, and has six children with ages between 7 years and 1 month.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell so as to expand her business

loans.name: Pepe

texts.es:
Pepe es socia del Bancomunal Fuerza y Poder.
Pepe  es del sur, tiene 33 años. es soltero, estudio  solo hasta primaria porque su mamá falleció, a los 13 años le ofrecieron darle trabajo y se vino a trabajar  para  L. ,  en el Terminal pesquero por varios años, hace dos años una amiga le da ropa a consignación para que venda, actualmente trabaja como cobrador y en la venta de ropa.
Pepe necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para la compra de camisas y pantalones de hombre.
Desde que está en Finca su negocio ha mejorado puede comprar más mercadería, ha podido comprarse un terreno en Pamplona.
El sueño pepe es tener una tienda en gamarra.
texts.en:
Pepe is a member of Fuerza y Poder Communal Bank.

Pepe is from the South, 33 years old and single. He only studied up until primary school because his mother died. At 13, he went to L. and worked in the fish market for several years. Two years ago a friend gave him clothing on consignment for him to sell. Now he works as a conductor and also sells clothing.

Pepe needs a loan of 800 soles to purchase men’s shirts and trousers. Since he has been working with FINCA, his business has improved, he can buy more merchandise and he has been able to purchase land in Pamplona.

Pepe dreams of having a shop in Gamarra.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase men's shirts and trousers

loans.name: Hak

texts.en: Mr. Hak C., 47, sells used motorbikes that he buys from people who live in rural areas. He buys motors at the cheapest price, cleans them up, and sells them at profit. The profit he gets from selling motorbikes is what he uses to feed his family. He is a responsible man who has provided for all his family's needs. Hak C. is the leader of three other family members. His wife is a good homemaker who cooks tasty meals for the family and cares for the children. Due to lack of capital needed to run the business more successfully, Hak C. would like a $1000 loan from Kiva to buy additional used motorcycles for sale.

loans.use: To buy additional used motorcycles

loans.name: Sohibchamol

texts.ru: Сохибчамол Гулматова проживает в районе гиссра. Возраст 48 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Сохибчамол имеет торговую точку на центральном рынке, где торгует растительным маслом. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 15 лет. Клиентка просит кредит, чтобы увеличить свой товараоборот.
texts.en:
Sohibchamol G. lives in the Gissar district. She is 48 years, married and has 2 children. Sohibchamol has a retail stand at the central market, where she sells vegetable oil. She has been involved in this business for over 15 years. Our client is requesting this loan in order to increase her product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase product turnover

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
Fred O. deals in secondhand clothes for men. Fred sells at the market square in his community. He also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Fred has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy bales of secondhand clothes.

Fred is 31 years old. He is married and has three children, all of whom are still school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in the busy commercial town of Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Fred works hard to be able to provide for his family. His aspiration is to sponsor all his children through school to the higher levels.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes

loans.name: Gilbert Group

texts.es:
Foto de Izquierda a derecha:  Teodora del Socorro Jarquín A., Lesbia Johana C. Téllez, María Teresa Sánchez y Lorena  del Carmen López Hernández.

El grupo solidario Gilbert está conformado por cuatro señoras, todas ellas son mujeres trabajadoras, originarias del departamento de Masaya, sus condiciones de vida son humildes, trabajan con Adim porque les gusta que confíen en ellas, expresaron..
Son vecinas, de confianza, se conocen hace muchos años y son muy unidas. 
. 

Doña  Teodora del Socorro Jarquín es la coordinadora del grupo, fue elegida por ser una persona muy responsable, es viuda, tiene una pulpería pequeña pero bien surtida de productos, tiene una hija de 15 años que estudia y le ayuda a ver el negocio, ella tiene varios años de dedicarse a esta actividad , sueña con mejorar el negocio y algún día tener una miscelánea para que su hija estudie y tenga una profesión.

Doña Lesbia Johana  joven mujer vende  chicha en bolsas y en botellas, ella distribuye a vendedores que ofrecen sus refrescos en los barrios y el mercado, actualmente tiene dos vendedores, en su casa también vende por unidades; con mas de cuatro años de dedicarse a esta actividad ha sacado su familia adelante, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos para sus tres hijos, él es educador social. Además vende ropa al crédito como segunda actividad. Sueña con darle estudios universitarios a sus hijos que están en edades de 16, 15 y 14 años.



Doña  María Teresa Sánchez es una joven mujer, madre de una niña de ocho años que estudia en una escuela cerca de su casa, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de cobertores, sábanas y fundas, compra sus materiales en el mercado como telas. hilos, adornos, etc., tiene muchos clientes que le piden encargos, sueña con tener su propia vivienda, ella es muy responsable.

Doña Lorena del Carmen López es una mujer propietaria de un pequeño salón de belleza
Ubicado en su casa de habitación, es madre de un solo hijo ya adulto, su esposo trabaja como guarda de seguridad en una empresa en Managua. Ella inició su negocio hace cinco años, primero fue trabajadora de un salón en el mercado. El crédito lo necesita para comprar materiales como líquidos de permanente, shampoo, pinturas cosméticas, etc.
Sueña con tener un salón más completo y mejorar su casa separando el salón del resto de la casa.

Este grupo está comprometido a pagar puntual y así seguir obteniendo créditos con Adim, están seguras que con el crédito saldrán adelante porque incrementan sus ventas y así sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Teodora del Socorro Jarquín A., Lesbia Johana C. Téllez, María Teresa Sánchez and Lorena del Carmen López Hernández (from left to right). The Gilbert solidary group is made up of 4 women, all of whom are hard-working and are from the department of Masaya. They live humble lives and work with Adim because they like that they trust them. They are neighbors that trust each other since they have known each other for many years and are very united. Mrs. Teodora del Socorro Jarquín is the coordinator of the group. She was elected because she is a very responsible person. She is a widow, and she has a small grocery store that is well-stocked with products. She has a 15-year-old daughter, who is in school. She dreams of improving her business and someday of having a general store so that her daughter can study and have a job. Mrs. Lesbia Johana is a young woman, who sells chicha (a type of beverage) in bags and in bottles. She distributes this to vendors, who offer her drinks in the neighborhoods and in the market. At present, she has two vendors. In her house, she also sells them individually. She has pursued this activity for more than 4 years, and she has taken her family forward. Her husband helps her with the expenses for their three children. He is a teacher. She also sells clothes on credit as a second job. She dreams of providing for her children to attend university. Her children as 16, 15, and 14 years old. Mrs. María Teresa Sánchez is a young woman. She has an eight-year-old daughter, who attends a school near her house. She makes and sells bedspreads, sheets, and pillowcases. She buys materials in the market, including fabric, threads, decoration, etc. She has many clients that give her orders for her products. She dreams of having her own home. She is very responsible. Mrs. Lorena del Carmen López is a woman who owns a small beauty salon, which is located in her house. She has one son, who is an adult. Her husband works as a security guard in a business in Managua. She began her business 5 years ago. At first, she was working in a salon in the market. The loan is needed to buy materials like liquids for perms, shampoo, cosmetics, etc. She dreams of having a more complete salon, to improve her house, and to separate her salon from her house. This group has promised to make their payments punctually, and this is how they continue to get loan from Adim. She are certain that with this loan they will go forward because they will be able to increase their sales and, therefore, their incomes.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various products, including beauty products

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander A. is from the village of Lapasan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is thirty-two years old. Alexander is married and has two school-age children. To make a living, Alexander owns and operates a service-based business, providing vulcanizing services to local community members. Alexander has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately $67 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Alexander joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation by engaging in business activities. He has successfully repaid previous loans from GDMPC. Alexander is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his eleventh loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the expansion to further improve his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa is already 60 years old. She is married to Wilfredo and they have seven children. Three were already married and four are still living with them.  Some of them are helping in the business while some are still studying.  The family resides peacefully in General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. 

Elisa wakes up early in the morning, keeping their house clean before she lives for work.  She sells dried fish and some vegetables around their village using her basket.  She wanted to avail a loan from the Kiva lenders amounting to PHP7, 000 as additional capital. The loan will enable her to buy more products. It will also enable her increase her vending income that will somehow satisfy her family needs.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Agness

texts.en:
Agness is a member of the Makunguu borrower group in Mwanjelwa, Mbeya. She is 50 year old woman, she is married and a mother of 3 children. Her children are 20,17,13 years old.

Agness has owned a charcoal business for 5 years, she works 10 hours a day and she earns a monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Agnes`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania, she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Agness hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Alicia Antonia

texts.es: Alicia Antonia T. D. M. resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán. Alicia tiene 59 años D. edad vive con su esposo quien se dedica a la agricultura y su nieto Julio D. 19 años D. edad estudiante universitario. Alicia posee su negocio D. productos para uso diario y pupuseria, ubicados en el mercado municipal D. Ahuachapán, con 20 años D. experiencia y antigüedad D. su negocio Alicia ha ganado gran cantidad D. clientes lo que le permite seguir expandiendo su negocio, es por ello que solita D. este crédito para compra D. productos que le permitan seguir creciendo en su negocio y poder aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Alicia Antonia lives is the department of Ahuachapan. Alicia is 59 years old, lives with her husband who is a farmer and with her grandson Julio (19 years old) who is a student at the university. Alicia has a store that carries products for daily use and grocery items. It is located in the municipal market of Ahuachapan. She has twenty years of experience and history in this business. Alicia has a large number of customers. This has allowed her to expand her business. It is because of this that she is asking for a loan to buy products that allow her to continue growing her business and increasing her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie F. wanted to strengthen the business she started and has been supporting through her loan in ASHI since her membership in 2008. With the larger amount of loan she is requesting right now, she will buy a motorized fishing boat and fishing gears for her husband to be able to fish more and to be able to fish in deeper parts of the ocean. For her own business, a small portion from her loan will be spent for growing her hogs/pigs.

The proceeds Elsie will be getting from her business will be used for repairing their house until such time wherein she can afford to rebuild a stronger and more concrete house to shelter her six children who range in age from two to 21 years old.  Elsie is also hopeful that despite the very poor economic condition her family is having right now, through her business and the assistance of loans she can request through ASHI, even one if not all of her children will graduate from college and their lives will be changed.

loans.use: To buy a motorized fishing boat and fishing gears for her husband  and fsupplies or her hog-raising business

loans.name: Oyinade

texts.en:
Oyinade O. is a 42-year-old married woman with four children. She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria.

For over eight years now, she has earned a living by selling wood. She has been with LAPO for the past two years. Oyinade is now requesting a loan in the amount of N100,000 ($675) to purchase more wood for resale purposes. She expresses her deep gratitude to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional wood

loans.name: Fredy

texts.es:
Fredy tiene 31 años, está casado y es padre de dos hijos, con los que vive en su casa. Casi siempre, se le encuentra con el machete en la mano, ya que tiene que estar constantemente quitando los arbustos, en aras de mantener limpias sus chacras de café y plátanos.
Ser agricultor le llena de mucha satisfacción, por eso prefiere dedicarse todo el día a ello, desde las 8 de la mañana hasta 5 de la tarde. La mayoría de las veces trabaja solo, pero para las cosechas su esposa lo apoya en la recolección de los granos. Una vez terminada la cosecha vende su café a las diversas acopiadoras de su zona.
Con las ganancias obtenidas compran los comestibles para el hogar por sacos, ya que el resto de los meses las cosechas de plátanos es para cubrir los gastos diarios.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por ello se encuentra muy motivado y hace el compromiso de pagar sus cuotas puntualmente. El dinero que solicita lo piensa invertir en la compra de fertilizantes químicos para sus cultivos de café.
texts.en:
Fredy is 31 years old. He is married and is the father of two children, with whom he lives in his house. Almost always, he is found with a machete in his hand, as he constantly has to cut back the trees from his ploughed land, in order to keep his coffee and banana farm clear. To be a farmer gives him much satisfaction, and because of this he prefers to spend all day on this work, from 8 in the morning until 5 in the afternoon. The majority of the time he works alone, but during the harvests his wife helps him to collect the beans. When the harvest is over, he sells his coffee to various collectors in his neighborhood. With the income that he obtains, they buy the food for the home by the sackful, so that in the rest of the months the harvest of bananas is to cover the daily expeneses. This is his first loan with MFP, because of this he is very motivated and has committed to pay his installments punctually. The money that he is asking for he thinks to invest in the purchase of chemical fertilizers for his coffee farm.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Mernie

texts.en:
Her father always told her that hard work, dedication and being responsible would lead to financial independence and a comfortable life. Mernie A., who is now 46, has always followed this wise counsel. Her husband Joeffrey is a farmer and also helps her run her business.  They live in Purok Mabinuligon, Brgy. Busay, Bago City, Negros Occidental with their 6 children, aged 14 to 25. One of their children already has a family, the 2 youngest are still in school, and the rest are working to help the family improve their lot. Mernie hopes that her business will continue to prosper so that she can earn enough to send her younger children to college and also to invest in other business ventures so that they can increase their family income.

As a mother who went through a lot of sacrifices while she was growing up because her family was very poor, Mernie does not want her children to go through the same difficulties of having to earn a living just to help support the family. When she got married, she decided to start her own business by opening a general store. She also raised livestock like pigs and ducks in her backyard, but she stopped this at some point because she needed to revolve her capital faster, and so decided to concentrate on expanding her general store operations.

In 2001, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access the necessary capital to expand and diversify her business. As the years passed and she continued to maintain her good credit record, her loans allowed her to sell rice and eggs in addition to her general store. From her business income she was able to buy a small plot of land to grow rice. From her business activities she is able to earn a monthly income of PHP 4,000.

Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 was used as additional working capital for her general store and rice business. She was able to repay this amount on time within her loan term. Now she is borrowing PHP 19,500 as additional working capital for her general store and rice business.  This will be her 18th loan. She intends to save some of the additional income for the education of her children, and use some to buy piglets to raise to expand her business.
 
About NWTF:
  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for general store

loans.name: María Eugenia

texts.es: María Eugenia M. R. de 53 años de edad, reside en el departamento de La Libertad, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos. Ella tiene su propio negocio en el cual se encarga de hacer pupusas y de elaborar almuerzos. María es muy solicitada por las personas, debido a que es muy aseada y excelente cocinera, ya que posee más de cinco años de experiencia en la cocina. María solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar materia prima como maíz, frijoles y queso para la elaboración de la comida. Esto debido a que desea poder atender una mayor cantidad de clientes y esto es posible si solamente cuenta con más materia prima.
texts.en:
María Eugenia M. R., 53, lives in the La Libertad department with her husband and their three children. She has her own business; she makes “pupusas” (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables) and prepares lunches. María is is very popular because she is a very clean and excellent cook. She has over five years experience in the kitchen. María is asking for a loan to be able to buy raw material like corn, beans, and cheese to make food. This is because she wants to be able to take care of a larger quantity of customers. It is only possible if she has the raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material to make food

loans.name: Fermina De Los Ángeles

texts.es: Fermina de los Ángeles A. R. de 34 años de edad, reside en San Juan Opico, ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad. Vive junto a su hermana, su pequeña hija de 6 años de edad y sus sobrinos. Ella posee una venta de cosméticos y perfumes, los cuales los comercializa de manera ambulante, ya que va de casa en casa ofreciendo sus productos. Ella compra al contado, es por esto que solicita un préstamo para poder comprar mayor cantidad de mercadería ya que en muchas ocasiones sus clientes le piden algún tipo de productos y para ella es imposible obtenerlo debido a que no cuenta con el capital necesario para poder comprarlo, así mismo por el tipo de trabajo que posee y a las personas a la cuales les vende su producto muchas veces se ve en la necesidad de dar los cosméticos y perfumes a crédito, dinero el cual ella debe reponer. Fermina trabaja arduamente por el bienestar de su hija, ya que es ella la única que provee para los gastos de la niña.
texts.en:
Fermina de los Ángeles A. R. is 34 years old and lives in San Juan Opico, located in the department of La Libertad. She and her six-year-old daughter live with her sister and her children. She sells cosmetics and perfumes as a street vendor, going from house to house offering her products. She buys her merchandise on a retail basis. She is asking for a loan to be able to buy more inventory since often her customers ask her for a particular item and she can't get it since she doesn't have enough capital. She is also asking for a loan because given the nature of her job and her customer base, many customers need to make their purchases using credit, something she doesn't have the funds to offer. Fermina works hard for the well-being of her daughter since she is her sole provider.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics and perfumes

location.town: San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
Nuestra socia es la señora LUZ MARINA, ella pertenece al banco comunal “MUJERES UNIDAS”, la socia es  natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 61 años de edad es casada, tiene 3 hijos, (39, 37, 31) años de edad, La socia tiene un pequeño hospedaje , que apertura en su casa propia ubicado en el barrio de Quispicanchis en la misma ciudad del Cusco, nuestra socia está terminando de ampliar dos baños en su casa para mayor comodidad y solicita para ello el préstamo, el cual le permitirá terminar con los acabados de los baños, nuestra socia trabaja con turismo y le encanta recibirlos en sus casas, ella recibe especialmente voluntarios que viene al país hacer sus aportes y conocedora de lo que les gusta trata de cubrir con los deseos de sus huéspedes. 

La socia agradece y expresa su satisfacción de poder seguir creciendo con su negocio propio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago  de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member is Señora LUZ MARINA, belonging to the communal bank “Women United”, living in the city of Cusco. She is 61, married, with 3 children ages 39, 37, and 31. She has a small guest house opening into her own house in the Quispicanchis neighborhood of Cusco. She is requesting a loan to finish enlarging the bathrooms in her house for increased convenience. The loan will allow her to put the finishing touches in the bathrooms. Working in tourism, she enjoys receiving people into her house, especially volunteers who come to invest in the country. She is expert in pleasing her guests and tries to satisfy their requests. She is grateful and satisfied to be able to grow her own business, and she commits to repay her loan within the agreed period.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finish the upgrade of two bathrooms in her guest house

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en: Emelyn, age 44, farms for a living. She is married and has three children who go to school. She works hard to help her family have an income to sustain their needs. She also strives to give her children a proper education. She plants rice crops and makes sure that they grow healthily on her farm. She joined CEVI to assist her business financially. Her previous loans were used to fund her farm. She is now requesting a loan of 14,000 PHP to be used for acquiring necessary farm supplies like seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Armando I. is from the village of Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 52 years old. Armando is married and has 3 adult children. Armando owns & operates a tricycle transport service. Armando has been engaged in his business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Armando joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Armando has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Armando is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle so that he can offer better service. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Armando from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle so he can offer better service

loans.name: Adelaida's Group

texts.en:
Adelaida V., from the village of Centro Sur, Alcala, Cagayan, is the 58-year-old group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

A married mother of five grown children, Adelaida raises pigs for fattening and sale. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,400 whenever she sells her raised animal.

In 2010, Adelaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase livestock to raise and sell in the future, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 56 years old, married and has four children. He has been rearing poultry in his farm for eight years. He sells eggs and broilers to hotels and to local residents for special events such as weddings. He also grows vegetables and rears dairy cattle for commercial purposes. He was previously an employee before he retired to operate this business. 

He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for training him on managing his business because his business has improved.  He hopes to expand his business and to increase the market territory for his products. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy broilers and chicken feed.

loans.use: To buy broilers and chicken feed

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia’s biggest dream is to have a successful pig farm someday. She believes this opportunity will give her the confidence to succeed while helping her family rise out of poverty. The financial opportunity of hog fattening is one of the best ways to help provide for her family and she very much wants to lift her family out of financial difficulties.  Over the years she has provided for her family by involving herself in hog raising including slaughtering and tends to a poultry business in her village.

This loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos is for hog fattening, a common business for people in her area affliction from poverty. Alicia will buy two piglets, sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets. She will raise them for approximately four to six months until they are ready for sale.

With the support of ASHI and its partner, Kiva  she is hopeful that her hog fattening business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To buy two piglets, sacks of feed, and supplements and vitamins for the piglets.

loans.name: Nirosha

texts.en:
Nirosha is a 28-year-old married woman living with two daughters in the town of Telijjawila, in the Matara district of southern Sri Lanka. 

She has been running her business, a small grocery shop, for two years now.  She is very hardworking and has gained a great amount of experience.
 
Nirosha has requested a 30,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to purchase goods for her grocery store.  She hopes to supply a nutritious diet for her family through the income from her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To buy goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Natiq

texts.en:
Natiq M. is a 37-year-old man who sells construction tools and home products in his store in the small village of Saatli. He always buys certified and high-quality goods which makes his shop very attractive to customers. He is married and has two children.

Natiq applied for a 1,000 AZN loan to increase the volume of his merchandise. He believes this will also increase his profit which will allow him to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Zambarau Group

texts.en:
Meet Hawa S. and the Zambarau Group. Hawa is 27 years old and married with a two-year-old son. She also supports her 19 year-old sister, and they work together at Hawa's shop. She has been running the business for two years and it is going well. The shop is open from 7 am until 8:30 pm daily, and Hawa earns a profit of about $115 (160,000 Tsh) per month. This will be Hawa's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, and she will use it to purchase additional inventory of sugar, rice and beans, which sell the fastest at her shop. Hawa will use the profits from this loan to purchase more stock and expand her inventory. She dreams of growing the business and eventually adding a beauty saloon.  

Hawa is the treasurer of her group, Zambarau. At Tujijenge Tanzania, the groups name themselves, and Zambarahau is the name of a local fruit. The group's 18 members run a variety of businesses including selling clothes, food, meat and motorcycle maintenance.  Members hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.  

Hawa is in the middle of the photo, wearing an orange dress with a white scarf.

loans.use: buying supplies of sugar, rice and beans.

loans.name: Glenda Monserrate

texts.es:
La señora Glenda forma  parte del Banco Comunal Mujeres Del Futuro desde hace un ciclo, este banco pertenece a la ciudad de Portoviejo, se reúne en las ciudadela Las Orquídeas, nuestra socia está dedicada al comercio de ropa como:pantalones, blusas, ropa de niños, interiores; inició este negocio motivada por su sobrina quien  le ofreció viajar hasta la ciudad de Guayaquil para comprarle la mercadería en los grandes mayorista de la bahía, en ocasiones ha tenido que realizar las compras en Portoviejo.

La señora Glenda esta felizmente casada desde hace 22 años, tiene 2 hijos.

 Esta muy contenta trabajando con los créditos que ha obtenido de la Fundación, su negocio lo tiene en el cantón Santa Ana a media hora de distancia de la capital manabita, todos los días se traslada junto a su esposo a vender la mercadería, tiene un local en el mercado del cantón, lo abre desde las 7 de la mañana hasta las 3 de la tarde que termina la feria. Con este nuevo crédito podrá invertir  en el negocio, sus ventas las realiza al contado, tiene bastantes clientes le va muy bien, tanto así que esta pagando un local en un centro comercial de la ciudad de Portoviejo para poder ayudarse en el hogar.
texts.en:
Sra. Glenda has been a member of the Communal Bank “Mujeres del Futuro” (Women of the Future) for one loan cycle. This Communal Bank meets in the community of Las Orquídeas, which is part of the city of Portoviejo. Glenda sells clothing such as trousers, blouses, undergarments, and children’s outfits. She started this business after she was encouraged by her niece, who offered to travel to the city of Guayaquil to buy merchandise from the large wholesalers. At times she has to make her purchases in Portoviejo.

Sra. Glenda has been happily married for 22 years and has two children.

She is very happy to be working with the loans obtained through Fundación ESPOIR. Her business is located in the canton of Santa Ana, which is 30 minutes away from the capital of Manabita. Every day she travels with her husband to sell her merchandise. She has a stand at the market in the canton, which is open from 7am until the fair closes at 3pm. With this new loan, she plans to invest in her business. Her sales are made for cash and she has enough customers to help her do well. She is even paying for a stand at a shopping center in the city of Portoviejo to help with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase blouses, trousers, undergarments, t-shirts, etc.

loans.name: Marisa

texts.en:
Marisa B., from the village of Mialem, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental, is 41 years old, married, and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Marisa owns and operates a service-based business providing mechanical services such as motor repairs to local community members. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Marisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 7,000.00 PHP from GDMPC, she is now requesting a new loan, her fourth, of 5000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her business. Marisa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
This is Rosario B., a widow at age 43, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She has four children and three grandchildren, courtesy of her oldest child. Her three younger children are still in elementary school.

Rosario operates a buy-and-sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.65 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Rosario dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Emile

texts.en:
Emile is 34 years old and married with five children between 5 and 13 years old.  Emile is commonly known for selling clothes and he has been in this business for about 15 years.  The starting business hours are 7 am and the closing hours are 6 pm every day.

Emile wishes to start selling styles for women but unfortunately, his capital is still too low.  To end this, Emile needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, as his business will be expanded, Emile will hopefully increase the number of customers as well as profits.  With these profits, Emile will keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase different styles of women's clothes

loans.name: Catherine

texts.es:
Catherine vive en la zona de Alto irpavi de la ciudad de La Paz.
Es soltera y no tiene hijos.
La cliente, egresada de la carrera de arquitectura,  se dedica a la supervisión de obras y dirección de obras, por lo que el préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de cerámica para terminar una obra fina y así entregar la construcción terminada a sus dueños y recibir el pago por sus servicios. De esta manera, ella está creando una nueva forma de percibir ingresos en forma más rápida y eficiente.
Es la primera vez que solicita el crédito y la primera que requiere el apoyo de kiva.
texts.en:
Catherine lives in the Alto Irpavi neighborhood of the city of La Paz. She is single and has no children. Catherine has a degree in architecture, and supervises and directs construction projects. She will invest the loan requested in the purchase of tile to complete the finish work on a job so that she can deliver the completed construction to the owners and receive payment for her services. In this way, she can earn income in a more rapid and efficient manner. This is the first time that she has requested a loan, and the first time she has sought support from Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy tiles to complete the finishing touches on a construction project that she is supervising

loans.name: Kunama Group

texts.fr:
Estella N. est une commerçante âgée de 42 ans qui habite  à Rugombo dans la Province de Cibitoke située à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme le grain de maïs et le haricot au Marché de Cibitoke.C’est un métier qu’elle exerce il ya de cela 25 ans. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e année des études primaires. C’est une veuve de Ezéchiel Nyandwi. Elle fait juste le 1er  cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 8enfants et ceux qui sont à l’école sont âgés de 17ans,15ans,12ans et 9ans. 
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de produits alimentaires (maïs et haricot) à vendre dans l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice. Elle espère avoir son propre capital dans l’avenir qui lui permettra de faire un grand business et réaliser ses projets comme la construction de sa propre maison en matériaux durables, assurer la scolarité de ses enfants et réaliser les autres rêves de sa vie.
 
 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « Kunama».
texts.en:
Estella N. is a 42 year old shopkeeper who lives in Rugombo in the Cibitoke province, which is in the west of Burundi. She sells food products such as corn seeds and beans at the Cibitoke market, and has been involved in this activity for around 25 years. She attended school up until the sixth year of elementary. She is Ezéchiel Nyandwi's widow and is on her first microcredit loan application with Turame . She has 8 children, all of whom attend school, and are aged 17, 15, 12 and 9. She is seeking a Kiva loan in order to increase her stock levels, so that she may generate higher profits. She aims to use her own funds in future to enlarge her business, build a house from hardy materials, see to her children's education and realise other goals. She is a member of the 'Kunama' solidarity group.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: boost stock levels (corn and beans) in order to generate higher profits

loans.name: Jamshed

texts.en:
K. Jamshed is 31 years old. He is married with 4 children. Jamshed has a small restaurant where he sells breakfast, lunch and dinner. Prior to opening his own business, he worked at a restaurant where he learned the ins and outs of the trade. 

When Jamshed first started his business, he only opened to sell breakfast because he worked at night. Once his place became more popular, he was able to dedicate his whole time to the business. 

Jamshed wants the loan so he may invest in tables, chairs and utensils. He is asking for a loan of 3000 USD. With this money, Jamshed will be able to expand his business, to earn more profit and in turn help his children move forward to complete their school studies and further continue studying at the university. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing tables, chairs and utensils to expand his cafe business

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.es: Maria Del Socorro tiene 67 años, su actividad es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más de 17 años que tiene este negocio por lo que ha demostrado ser una persona muy emprendedora y que disfruta de su trabajo. Este negocio inicio por que anteriormente se dedicaba a trabajar de enfermera, con el paso del tiempo es que aprendió de este oficio, pues con muy poco capital y con esfuerzos propios es que ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de materia prima como sabanas, toallas, calzado, cosméticos y ropa en general. Ella sueña con establecer una tienda de ropa.
texts.en:
Maria Del Socorro is 67 years old, and her job is selling general merchandise. She has been doing this business for more than 17 years, and she is a very hardworking person that enjoys her work. Her business began because earlier she had worked as a nurse, but over time she learned this work. So with very little capital and from her own efforts he has been able to succeed in her business. The loan that she requests is for the purchase of materials like sheets, towels, shoes, cosmetics and clothing. She dreams of opening her own clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Amy Schapiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina T. earns her living by operating a networking business. Her husband, Rolando T., age 57, works as an electrician to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children between the ages of 7 and 24. Two of her children are already working while the other four attend school. The family lives in Prk. Caticong, Brgy. Cabadiangan, Compostela, Cebu City. 

Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired toward something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gina  has been working hard and incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,000, which has helped raise the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 23,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her networking business so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Gina T. is truly a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable." Through this alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities they could not have imagined. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Paulette

texts.fr: G. Paulette est née en 1976 et est mariée à ADJOVI Jean-Paul. Le couple a un enfant qui est scolarisé et qui vit avec eux. Il y a environs six ans que Paulette s’est installée avec sa famille au quartier Agongbomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Paulette assure avec son mari les charges de la famille. Depuis sept ans, Paulette vend des ustensiles de cuisine, et de façon secondaire, des cartes de recharges téléphoniques et des divers à son domicile. Paulette achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est la deuxième fois que Paulette sollicite auprès de ALIDé un crédit, en vue de rehausser le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients. Le premier crédit dont Paulette a bénéficié a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Paulette G. was born in 1976 and is married to Jean-Paul ADJOVI. The couple has one child who lives with them and attends school. About six years ago, Paulette and her family moved to the neighborhood of Agongbomey, in Cotonou, Benin's economic capital. Together, Paulette and her husband provide for their family.

For the past seven years, Paulette has been selling kitchen utensils from her home. She also sells mobile phone recharge cards and various items. She gets her stocks in Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. 

This is Paulette’s second time seeking a loan from ALIDé to bolster her business and better meet customer demand. The first loan she received was fully repaid.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen utensils and various items

loans.name: Duval Enrique

texts.es: Duval Enrique tiene 37 años, se dedica al destace de cerdos. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, el siempre ha sido un hombre muy responsable y además siempre se ha hecho cargo de sus 1 hijo, por lo que tenía que buscar un medio de ingreso para su familia, y fue así que comenzó este negocio pero su dificultad es encontrar a un buen cerdo y que últimamente ha sido muy difícil mantener el alimento de estos animales, a pesar de estas dificultades  ha logrado salir adelante. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo. El sueña con proporcionarle a su hijo una mejora calidad de vida y obtener mejores ganancias.
texts.en: Duval Enrique is 37 years old and raises hogs.  He’s been doing this for more than 10 years and has always been a responsible man who cares for his son.  He stated in this business because he needed to find a source of income for his family, but lately he has had trouble finding good hogs and maintaining their feed.  Despite these difficulties, he has managed to come out ahead.  He is requesting this loan to use as working capital.  He wants to provide his son with a better quality of life and increase his income.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Dorah

texts.en:
Dorah is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is house rent. 

Dorah has operated a retail shop for the past six months. Her potential customers are passersby and neighbors. In addition she sells cloth which is another source of income. Dorah faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to have a wholesale shop in the future.

Dorah decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to improve her business. With a Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of sugar, cooking oil and wheat flour for resale.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of sugar, cooking oil and wheat flour for resale.

loans.name: Piedra Grande Group

texts.es:
La señora Alicia Sánchez M., vive en la localidad de: "Piedra Grande" municipio de coapilla estado de Chiapas México, es casada con tres hijo que aun están a su cargo, la primera es Daniela  Yazmín de once años, el otro es Antonio de ocho años de edad, Freddy de cuatro y el mas pequeño es Rafael de dos años.

         Éste ya es el tercer présatamo que pide a Fundación Realidad y los dos préstamos anteriores los ha invertido en la compra y venta de pollos y en la carpintería que trabaja su esposo, comenta  que con esta actividad le ha ido bien ya que les a dado buenos ingresos en su hogar.

        Se inspiró en esta actividad de venta de pollos por que también quiría ayudar con los gastos que se generan en su familia y así su esposo se sienta apoyado con más ánimo de salir adelante.

        Con la ganancia que va obteniendo, lo invierte en la compra de más pollos y madera para su carpintería que también los ha poyado mucho con el gasto que se mantiene del diario.

       Su  sueño más grande es que  logre ahorrar y apoyar a su esposo con sus ingresos y puedan salir adelante juntos como familia.

       En el programa se integro por los avisos que FRAC hizo en su localidad, en donde se vio muy interesada y busco otras personas mas para poder formar un grupo y fue así como formaron el grupo de nombre "Piedra Grande" por llamarse así el lugar en donde ellos viven.

     Las personas que integran el grupo son tres y son las siguientes:

    Alicia Sánchez M.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de pollos para venderlo aliñado, como tambien en la compra de pinturas y madera para su carpintería.
    Jesús M. Rodríguez: invierte el préstamo en la compra de pollos para luego venderlo aliñados (destazados), como tambien en la venta de tacos dorados.
    Eladia M. Rodríguez: compra pollos para venderlo aliñado (destazado).
texts.en:
Mrs. Alicia Sánchez M. lives in the village of Piedra Grande, in the municipality of Coapilla, Chiapas, Mexico. She is married with four children that are still under her roof. The eldest is Daniela Yazmin (11) followed by Antonio (8), Freddy (4) and the youngest Rafael (2).         

This will be her third loan from the Reality Foundation, and she invested the two previous loans in the purchase of chickens for resale and in her husband's carpentry business. She says that these business have been going well and that are providing an income for their household.

She started selling chickens because she wanted to help cover her family's expenses and she wanted her husband to feel supported and thus inspired to keep working hard.   

She is using her profits to purchase more chickens and wood for her husband's carpentry, which has also been a great help towards covering their expenses. 

Her dream is to be able to save money and support her husband, so that they can succeed together as a family.

She joined the group after reading FRAC advertisements posted in her neighborhood. She sought out other interested people, and they formed a group named Piedra Grande after the community they live in.

The three members of the group are as follows:
Alicia Sánchez M.: She will use the loan money to purchase chickens to sell them butchered and seasoned, as well as the purchase of wood and paintings for a separate carpentry business.

Jesús M. Rodríguez: He will use the money to purchase chickens, which he will butcher and season for resale. He also sells tacos dorados or flautas.

Eladia M. Rodríguez: She will use the money to purchase chickens, which she will butcher and season for resale.
